awd_titl_txt: Mathematical modeling and Computational Analysis of Cell Tissue Movement
awd_abstract_narration:
Cell locomotion plays an essential role during embryonic development, angiogenesis, tissue regeneration, the immune response, and wound healing in multicellular organisms.  The major problems to be addressed in this project are (i) movement by shape changes, (ii) modeling of the intracellular mechanics, and (iii) integration of signaling, actin dynamics and mechanics in an integrated computational model of cell movement.  Heretofore mathematical modeling has primarily focused on the mesenchymal mode, but the investigators first address the other end of the continuum.  The overall objective is to produce a unified description for locomotion in a three-dimensional extracellular matrix that integrates signaling and mechanics.  Movement by shape changes has not been studied in the context proposed, but it has recently been shown to be important in the movement of a number of cell types, and understanding the factors that affect the speed and efficiency of such movement is a challenging problem.  This project develops mathematical models that can be used to study and quantify the importance of various factors, such as properties of the surrounding medium, that affect the efficiency of movement.  The third component continues previous work by the principal investigator on signaling and will integrate a model of the control networks with the mechanical components that comprise the first topics.  This will lead to the first model that incorporates both signaling and mechanics, and will result in a computational tool that should be very useful to the broader community.

Cell movement is a very complex process that involves the spatial and temporal control and integration of a number of subprocesses, including the transduction of chemical or mechanical signals from the environment, intracellular biochemical responses, and translation of the intra- and extracellular signals into a mechanical response.  While many single-celled organisms use flagella or cilia to swim, there are two basic modes of movement used by eukaryotic cells that lack such structures--mesenchymal and amoeboid.  The former, which can be characterized as ?crawling? in fibroblasts or ?gliding? in keratocytes, involves the extension of finger-like pseudopodia and/or broad flat lamellipodia, whose protrusion is driven by actin polymerization at the leading edge. In the amoeboid mode, which does not rely on strong adhesion, cells are more rounded and employ shape changes to move--in effect 'jostling through the crowd' or 'swimming'.  However, recent experiments have shown that numerous cell types display enormous plasticity in locomotion, in that they sense the mechanical properties of their environment and adjust the balance between the modes. Thus pure crawling and pure swimming are the extremes on a continuum of locomotion strategies, but many cells can sense their environment and use the most efficient strategy in a given context.  This project uses innovative mathematical approaches to better understand the dynamics of cell locomotion, combining novel models with experimental data.  Additionally, the research team includes postdoctoral researchers and graduate students, with the project providing an opportunity to work in an inherently interdisciplinary field.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

por.por_cntn:
A major important area  of current research in biology focuses on cell
locomotion, from both the experimental and the mathematical modeling points of
view.  The reasons for this focus are twofold. Firstly, cell locomotion plays an
essential role during many basic processes in biology, including embryonic
development, angiogenesis, tissue regeneration, the immune response, and wound
healing in multicellular organisms. Moreover, the movement of tumor cells from
the site of origin to other parts of the body, a process called metastasis, is
responsible for a significant portion of deaths due to cancer. Movement is a
very complex process that involves the spatial and temporal control and
integration of a number of sub-processes, including the transduction of chemical
or mechanical signals from the environment, intracellular biochemical responses,
and translation of the intra- and extracellular signals into a mechanical
response.  Recent laboratory experiments have shown that numerous cell types
display enormous plasticity in locomotion, in that they sense the mechanical
properties of their environment and adjust the balance between different modes.
At one extreme is pure crawling and at the other is pure swimming, but many
cells can sense their environment and use the most efficient strategy in a given
context.

Our research had several major objectives. One was to understand how shape
changes can propel cells, the forces that drive the shape changes, and what
determines the efficiency of a stroke. In that regard we have developed
mathematical and computational models that enable us to study how cells can
propel themselves, either separately or collectively, and how the type of shape
change employed affects the speed and efficiency of movement. While our
investigations have focused primarily on movement of biological cells, some of
it can also be used to understand the movement of mini-robots, and thus lead to
better design of them.

Another major aspect of the research concerns the signaling networks that
control how the cell alters it's shape dynamically. The pathways involve
molecules that act as molecular switches that relay extracellular signals, both
receptor-mediated signals and mechanical signals transduced via molecular
contacts with the cellular environment. Experimental work by others has shed
light on the networks involved, but a synthesis of these results into an
integrated model that can predict how the balances between the pathways
determine which mode prevails has not been done in detail, but we have taken an
important first step by developing and analyzing a mathematical model of the
major components of the network that transduces extracellular chemical
signals. The model is based on the current experimental information and is able
to replicate numerous observations in several different cell types. Thus the 
predictions derived from the model can be used to guide future experiments,
which can then be used to refine the model as new facts emerge.


 
  The broader impact of the funded research lies in both the breadth of
  potential applications of the work, and in the scientific training of students
  and postdocs that were involved in the research.  The results will find
  applications in many normal processes involved in development, wound healing,
  the immune system and in aspects of cell division and in apoptosis, and adds
  to our understanding of cancer metastasis.  Our results on swimming in Stokes
  flows are applicable in robotics, where there is significant interest in
  designing mobile nano-robots or robotic `cells' powered by stored energy.
  Because there was a significant training component of the research that
  involved undergraduates, graduate students, and postdocs, it
  has contributed to the development of human resources in applied mathematics,
  specifically, in mathematical modeling and analysis of biological problems.

 


Last Modified: 12/01/2018
Modified by: Hans G Othmer
